text.p: The following are the main stories from Monday morning's Austrian newspapers.
- Chancellor Franz Vranitzky says he has yet to decide whether he will run for another term after the 1999 general elections.

- Savings bank Die Erste says it may get back in the race for government sell-off candidate Creditanstalt after it left an Austro-Italian-German consortium of bidders on Friday, hours before the group submitted a last-minute offer.
- Creditanstalt unit AVA Bank says operating profit fell to to 182.1 million schillings in 1995 from 268.6 million a year earlier.
- Vienna airport plans to expand its transit area for a total of 240 million schillings to prepare for implementation of European Union's Schengen agreement.
- Vienna bourse could see new impulses this week from series of blue-chip earnings due for release.
- Finance Minister Viktor Klima says last-minute bid for Creditanstalt lacks details, needs more information.
- Government considers tender for the country's third mobile phone license.
- 1995 was a good year for Austria's metal industry, but gains should be muted in the current year, the Chamber of Labour says in a study.
- OECD team visits Vienna to gather latest data for next OECD report on Austria.
